intro: Impatiens trilobata, commonly known as the three-lobed jewelweed, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, branched stems and heart-shaped leaves with three distinct lobes. The plant produces small, yellow-orange flowers that are clustered in pairs, often with a single leaf-like bract below each flower. Impatiens trilobata thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers attract various pollinators, including bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
